quiz.name: Module 2: Portfolio Risk and Return: Part II
quiz.subtopic: Module 2: Portfolio Risk and Return: Part II

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07006
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information:

  Standard Deviation of Returns  Beta
Asset 70% 1.8
Market portfolio 35% 1.0

The covariance between the returns of the asset and the market is closest to:

answerFeedback.028dd550-b879-42d0-95a4-efdc3b61c7ec: Incorrect because it is the systematic variance of the portfolio; βi2 × σm2 = 1.82 × 0.352 = 0.40.
answerFeedback.03e0a797-92b1-44e9-91db-46875b1714e6: Incorrect because it is the correlation coefficient, not the covariance, between the asset returns and the market portfolio returns; ρi,m = βi × σm/σi = 1.8 × 0.35/0.70 = 0.90. It is also the closest answer if the asset return variance is used in the correct formula instead of the market return variance; 1.8 × 0.702 = 0.88.
answerFeedback.7156652d-cd94-4e84-9253-8557bf1b440f: Correct because, given the beta of an asset (βi), the covariance between the asset returns (Ri) and the market portfolio returns (Rm) is given by: Cov(Ri,Rm) = βi × σm2 = 1.8 × 0.352 = 0.22.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Croitoru-10
entry.itemBody: The capital market line most likely consists of portfolios that:

answerFeedback.1bfb03c1-f688-41e0-a188-40fdec77fec4: Correct because the capital market line (CML) does not apply to all securities or assets but only to portfolios on the efficient frontier. The efficient frontier gives optimal combinations of expected return and total risk. Total risk and systematic risk are equal only for efficient portfolios because those portfolios have no diversifiable risk remaining. Thus, the CML holds only for well-diversified portfolios.
answerFeedback.c8883a69-54cf-40b5-a718-e1cdda090796: Incorrect because the nonsystematic risk of the market portfolio is zero, but not its systematic risk. Because nonsystematic risk is zero for well-diversified portfolios, such as the market portfolio, the total risk of a market portfolio and other similar portfolios is only systematic risk, which is βiσm. Therefore, portfolios on the CML have zero nonsystematic (not systematic) risk.
answerFeedback.c976142b-ed58-4131-b73b-8582caf2077d: Incorrect because the total risk of a market portfolio and other similar portfolios is only systematic risk, which is βiσm. Therefore, portfolios on the CML have nonsystematic risk equal to zero, not beta.

choices.itemBody: C. have nonsystematic risk equal to beta.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09969
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a security and the market:

Security's beta 0.35
Standard deviation of the security's returns 12%
Standard deviation of market returns 18%

The correlation between the security's returns and the market's returns is closest to:

answerFeedback.b82ebe20-d816-4a62-92eb-8543ec62bebf: Incorrect because it uses variances instead of standard deviations in the correct formula; ρi,m = βi × σm2/σi2 = 0.35 × (0.18)2/(0.12)2 = 0.788 ≈ 0.8.
answerFeedback.bf71fa05-d2dd-4ae1-b9db-5f11063330f7: Correct because βi = ρi,m × σi/σm, where ρi,m denotes the correlation between the asset returns and the market returns, and σi and σm denote the standard deviation of the asset returns and the market returns, respectively. Thus, correlation ρi,m = βi × σm/σi = 0.35 × 0.18/0.12 = 0.525 ≈ 0.5.
answerFeedback.f7173236-372d-4739-b533-d5de140dfc62: Incorrect because it confuses σi and σm and calculates ρi,m = βi × σi/σm = 0.35 × 0.12/0.18 = 0.233 ≈ 0.2. This answer is also obtained if, as an additional mistake, variances are used; ρi,m = βi × σi2/σm2 = 0.35 × (0.12)2/(0.18)2 = 0.156 ≈ 0.2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-11050
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a portfolio and the market:

  Return Standard Deviation of Returns Beta
Portfolio 11% 4% 1.2
Market 10% 3% 1.0

If the risk-free rate is 3%, Jensen's alpha for the portfolio is:

answerFeedback.1737c637-8d33-4ef7-b504-9e9b3d552c01:
Correct because Jensen's alpha is calculated as:

αp = Rp – [Rf + βp (Rm – Rf)]

αp = 11% – [3% + 1.2 × (10% – 3%)]

αp = 11% – 11.4% = –0.4%.
answerFeedback.682a14fb-1b3d-47d2-ac7f-b463a61ab6e6:
Incorrect because the portfolio's actual return and required return are reversed and Jensen's alpha is incorrectly calculated as:

αp = [Rf + βp (Rm – Rf)] – Rp

αp = [3% + 1.2 × (10% – 3%)] – 11% 

αp = 11.4% – 11% = 0.4%.
answerFeedback.7ee95fbc-7684-4916-b18c-2489b3e3770e:
Incorrect because the market return is used instead of the market risk premium and Jensen's alpha is incorrectly calculated as:

αp = Rp – [Rf + βp (Rm)]

αp = 11% – [3% + 1.2 × (10%)]

αp = 11% – 15% = –4%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08344
entry.itemBody: An analyst estimates the standard deviation of returns for the market portfolio to be 15% and the standard deviation of returns for a stock to be 25%. If the correlation of returns between the stock and the market portfolio is 0.6, the stock has:

answerFeedback.325bb3f1-2042-49e9-bcc8-abfc1614cae6: Incorrect because the company has a beta equal to one, which is the same as the beta of the market portfolio.
answerFeedback.7032026d-c113-48e4-95bd-5cfa9892c5e1: Incorrect because the company has a beta equal to one, which is the same as the beta of the market portfolio.
answerFeedback.91d1e7ca-69be-4bf4-893a-2a358121a693: Correct because the amount of systematic risk for a company is measured by the stock's beta. β = ρi,m × σi / σm = 0.60 × 0.25 / 0.15 = 0.15 / 0.15 = 1. Since the company's beta equals the market portfolio's beta (the market portfolio's beta with itself equals 1), the company has the same level of systematic risk as the market portfolio.

choices.itemBody: A. less systematic risk than the market portfolio.
B. the same systematic risk as the market portfolio.
C. more systematic risk than the market portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10297
entry.itemBody: The intercept on the y-axis of the security characteristic line is:

answerFeedback.4a17019b-c446-4379-90c0-96d722132a3f: Incorrect because the risk-free rate of return is the intercept on the y-axis of the security market line, whereas Jensen's alpha is the intercept on the y-axis of the security characteristic line.
answerFeedback.b5ab4988-3e14-469c-8fe2-36d47fad0d7f: Incorrect because beta is the slope of the security characteristic line (SCL), not the intercept.
answerFeedback.c163f04d-1b51-40e3-a8b4-ee6067fd3cbb: Correct because the SCL is a plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market. Jensen's alpha is the intercept and the beta is the slope.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10670
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information:

Risk-free rate 4%
Expected return on a security 7%
Expected return on the market 14%

According to the CAPM, the security's beta is closest to:

answerFeedback.02c5e372-9d20-4102-95b9-8d4181931b5d:
Incorrect because it is simply the expected return for the security divided by the expected return for the market; 7%/14% = 0.50.

It is also closest to the value obtained when omitting the risk-free rate on the left-hand side of the calculation; [E(Ri)]/[E(Rm) – Rf] = [7%]/[14% – 4%] = 0.70.

This is also [E(Rm) – E(Ri)]/[E(Rm) – Rf] = (14% – 7%)/(14% – 4%) = 0.70.
answerFeedback.ac4a1d48-46f4-4a58-87c6-0612f53da72b:
Correct because, according to the CAPM, the expected return [E(Ri)] for an asset is given by: E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf].

The beta [βi] is then calculated using: βi = [E(Ri) – Rf]/[E(Rm) – Rf] = [7% – 4%]/[14% – 4%] = 0.30.
answerFeedback.db326c99-de5a-41e2-8d46-f293f58827e8: Incorrect because it uses the expected return on the market, not the market risk premium, in the calculation. Namely, it uses: [E(Ri) – Rf]/[E(Rm)] = [7% – 4%]/14% = 0.21.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10720
entry.itemBody: A security with a beta of 1.5 has an expected return of 11% according to the CAPM. If the risk-free rate is 2%, the market risk premium is closest to:

answerFeedback.28816486-03fc-4ec8-9f59-35d65c9f0d33: Correct because, according to the CAPM, the expected return of a security is E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf], such that [E(Rm) – Rf ]= [E(Ri) – Rf]/βi = (0.11 – 0.02)/1.5 = 0.06 = 6%. The market risk premium is E(Rm) – Rf = 6%.
answerFeedback.90bf206c-0aa8-43b7-8253-3aadc285f628:
Incorrect because it uses an incorrect CAPM equation to calculate the expected return of a security as E(Ri) = βi × [E(Rm) – Rf], such that [E(Rm) – Rf ] = E(Ri)/βi = 0.11/1.5 = 0.0733 ≈ 7.3%. The market risk premium is incorrectly calculated as 7.3%.

This is also closest to the market return of 8% calculated according to the CAPM equation; 0.11 = 0.02 + 1.5× [E(Rm) – 0.02]; E(Rm) = 0.08 = 8%.
answerFeedback.d1a28529-6263-49d2-af6d-fbaaf47870d4: Incorrect because it uses an incorrect CAPM equation to calculate the expected return of a security as E(Ri) = Rf + βi × E(Rm), such that E(Rm) = [E(Ri) – Rf]/βi = (0.11 – 0.02)/1.5 = 0.06 = 6%. Since the market risk premium is Rm – Rf, it follows that the market risk premium is calculated as 6% – 2% = 4%.

entry.title: ITEM_2019BPM04AHC
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information:

Risk-free rate 2%
Expected return of the market portfolio 10%
Standard deviation of the market portfolio 20%
Standard deviation of the security 35%
Correlation between the security and the market 0.8

According to the CAPM, the expected return of the security is closest to:

answerFeedback.105c804e-274b-4578-b43a-ca11e4e138c3: Incorrect because the risk-free rate is not included in the calculation of the market risk premium. Beta is calculated as β = (0.8 × 35%)/20% = 1.4. Therefore, using the CAPM equation: E(Ri) = 2% + 1.4 × (10%) = 16.0%.
answerFeedback.ae347ade-817f-4c59-aa0d-efb123acc378: Correct because the expected return of the security can be calculated using the CAPM equation: E(Ri) = Rf + β[E(Rm) – Rf]. The beta of the security can be calculated using the equation β = (ρi,m × σi)/σm. Therefore, β = (0.8 × 35%)/20% = 1.4. Beta is the product of the asset’s correlation with the market with a ratio of standard deviations of return (i.e., the ratio of the asset’s standard deviation to the market’s). Therefore, using the CAPM equation: E(Ri) = 2% + 1.4 × (10% − 2%) = 13.2%.
answerFeedback.bb1534be-075d-4212-9626-ecb6d6cf92a9: Incorrect because the security beta is wrongly calculated due to the reversal of the standard deviations of the security and the market portfolio. Therefore, the beta is calculated as β = (0.8 × 20%)/35% = 0.457. Next, using the CAPM equation, E(Ri) = Rf + β[E(Rm – Rf)], the expected return of the security is calculated as E(Ri) = 2% + 0.457 × (10% − 2%) = 5.66% ≈ 5.7%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Tsependa-11
entry.itemBody: The correlation between the risk-free asset and the optimal risky portfolio is expected to be:

answerFeedback.1ca9092c-12c7-4bbe-8b64-74c99b945ede: Incorrect because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. The optimal risky portfolio is a risky asset, and thus has zero correlation with the risk-free asset.
answerFeedback.9de50d91-0fa9-44e8-aaed-c71b5ba42ac7: Correct because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. The optimal risky portfolio is a risky asset, and thus has zero correlation with the risk-free asset.
answerFeedback.fcc0dd98-012d-4d32-a441-3ea812a248a1: Incorrect because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. The optimal risky portfolio is a risky asset, and thus has zero correlation with the risk-free asset.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Y.Zhang-10
entry.itemBody: Which of the following performance measures is equal to the slope of the capital allocation line?

answerFeedback.69f36144-615f-422f-964b-97a91d533eab: Correct because the Sharpe ratio, also called the reward-to-variability ratio, is simply the slope of the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.cc86a34f-2454-44ae-9f22-5de5005b85a8: Incorrect because the Treynor ratio corresponds to the slope of the security market line, not the capital allocation line. The Treynor ratio is a simple extension of the Sharpe ratio and resolves the Sharpe ratio's first limitation by substituting beta (systematic risk) for total risk.
answerFeedback.f5b3abc1-3203-4599-991b-ac98fe2cd0c1: Incorrect because M2 provides a measure of portfolio return that is adjusted for the total risk of the portfolio relative to that of some benchmark. While M2 is related to the Sharpe ratio, it is calculated in a different way and is measured in different units, therefore it does not represent the slope of the capital allocation line.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Chua-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a portfolio and the market:

Portfolio's Sharpe ratio 0.8
Volatility of portfolio returns 19%
Volatility of market returns 10%
Correlation between portfolio returns and market returns 0.7

The portfolio's Treynor ratio is closest to:

answerFeedback.0bf673cc-7f2a-45e2-8fce-a7fac23b15d0:
Incorrect because

0.413 = SR × (σp/βp*) = 0.8 × (0.19/0.368),

where

βp* = incorrectly calculated portfolio beta = ρpm(σm/σp) = 0.7 × (0.1/0.19) = 0.368.
answerFeedback.23479673-b4d2-4d8c-a2d4-db9bddd8c1a6:
Correct because

TR = (Rp – Rf)/βp = [(Rp – Rf)/σp] × (σp/<βp) = SR × (σp/βp) = 0.8 × (0.19/1.33) = 0.114,

where

σm = standard deviation of market returns = 0.10 (given);

σp = standard deviation of portfolio returns = 0.19 (given);

ρp,m = correlation between market and portfolio = 0.7 (given);

βp = portfolio beta = ρp,m(σp/σm) = 0.7 × (0.19/0.1) = 1.33 (per βi = ρi,m(σi/σm));

Rp = portfolio's return;

Rf  = risk-free rate of interest;

TR = Treynor ratio;

SR = Sharpe ratio, where SR = (Rp – Rf)/σp.
answerFeedback.9a5a64ff-a536-4e1b-9aac-6973a5d2974f:
Incorrect because

0.060 = SR × (σp/βp') = 0.8 × (0.19/2.527),

where

βp' = incorrectly calculated portfolio beta = ρpm(σp2/σm2) = 0.7 × (0.192/0.12) = 2.527.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Croitoru-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following lines is plotted on a graph with the excess return of a security on the y-axis and the excess return of the market on the x-axis?

answerFeedback.2949524e-1bac-4219-af4b-8583acbd1652: Incorrect because the capital market line is a special case of the capital allocation line, where the risky portfolio is the market portfolio. The capital market line is shown in Exhibit 3, where the standard deviation (σp), or total risk, is on the x-axis and expected portfolio return, E(Rp), is on the y-axis.
answerFeedback.305a5a7e-f02a-4682-9166-0abb9e5e4cce: Incorrect because the security market line represents a graph of the capital asset pricing model. The security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. Using the same concept as the capital market line, the SML intersects the y-axis at the risk-free rate of return, and the slope of this line is the market risk premium, Rm – Rf.
answerFeedback.f2eddeba-d9b6-4145-96da-9943e4dc0bb3: Correct because similar to the SML (security market line), we can draw a security characteristic line (SCL) for a security. The SCL is a plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market. The security characteristic line can also be estimated by regressing the excess security return, Ri – Rf, on the excess market return, Rm – Rf.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Croitoru-13
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about the security market line (SML) and a stock:

Intercept of the SML 2%
Slope of the SML 5%
Stock's beta 1.3

According to capital market theory, if the analyst believes the stock will have a return of 7%, the stock is:

answerFeedback.1799f31f-2454-4cc0-949e-589b5b94f4d1: Incorrect because the analyst forecasts the return of the asset to be 7%, which is lower than the expected return of 8.5% according to the CAPM. Thus, the security does not plot on the SML and it is not properly valued according to the CAPM. This response would be chosen if beta was omitted in the CAPM equation and the expected return of the asset was wrongly computed as 0.02 + 0.05 = 0.07 = 7.0%, which would imply that the asset plots on the SML.
answerFeedback.3707d967-6262-42ff-83bd-6a76e82ddd9e: Incorrect because the analyst forecasts the return of the asset to be 7%, which is lower than the expected return of 8.5% according to the CAPM. Thus, the security plots below the SML and should be considered overvalued. This response would be chosen if the expected return of the asset was wrongly computed as 0.02 + 1.3 × (0.05 – 0.02) = 0.059 = 5.9%, which would imply that the asset plots above the SML.
answerFeedback.c7fe869e-121e-4e04-8a09-8d13ef2142e9: Correct because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. Using the same concept as the capital market line, the SML intersects the y-axis at the risk-free rate of return, and the slope of this line is the market risk premium, Rm – Rf . Potential investors can plot a security’s expected return and beta against the SML and use this relationship to decide whether the security is overvalued or undervalued in the market. All securities that reflect the consensus market view are points directly on the SML (i.e., properly valued). If a point representing the estimated return of an asset is above the SML, the asset has a low level of risk relative to the amount of expected return and would be a good choice for investment. In contrast, if the point representing a particular asset is below the SML, the stock is considered overvalued. The asset will be on the SML if the forecasted return equals the expected return of 0.02 + 1.3 × 0.05 = 0.085 = 8.5%. Since the analyst forecasts the return of the asset to be 7%, which is lower than the expected return according to the CAPM, the security plots below the SML and should be considered overvalued.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Tsependa-13
entry.itemBody: The security market line applies:

answerFeedback.13c82615-b5ff-4c06-b72c-b96e1eb257f9: Incorrect because the security market line applies to any security, efficient or not. Total risk and systematic risk are equal only for efficient portfolios because those portfolios have no diversifiable risk remaining. The latter risk is also called idiosyncratic risk.
answerFeedback.4ee9830b-3739-4b51-bd28-ac2bde9acf9b: Incorrect because the security market line applies to any security, efficient or not, as opposed to the capital market line, which does not apply to all securities or assets but only to portfolios on the efficient frontier.
answerFeedback.699cca3f-bd10-4c7d-bc06-25cba7393c00: Correct because the security market line applies to any security, efficient or not. The security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis.

choices.itemBody: B. only to efficient securities.
C. only to securities that have idiosyncratic risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Croitoru-14
entry.itemBody: The market has a return of 8% and a standard deviation of returns of 12%. The risk-free rate is 2%. If a portfolio has a Sharpe ratio of 0.8, the portfolio's M2 alpha is closest to:

answerFeedback.c26175c1-f6fa-413e-af4b-facb97aa43e9: Correct because M2 provides a measure of portfolio return that is adjusted for the total risk of the portfolio and is computed as M2 = [E(Rp) − Rf](σm/σp) + Rf = SR × σm + Rf , where SR = Sharpe ratio, σm = market standard deviation of returns, and Rf = risk-free rate. Thus, M2 = 0.8 × 0.12 + 0.02 = 0.116. The difference between the risk-adjusted performance of the portfolio and the performance of the market is frequently referred to as M2 alpha. Thus, M2 alpha = 0.116 – 0.08 = 0.036 = 3.6%.
answerFeedback.e793fb58-3bc3-44e5-adb4-09b9b148b1b7: Incorrect because it computes M2 = 0.02 + 0.8 × 0.12 = 0.116. M2 alpha is wrongly calculated as 0.116 – (0.08 – 0.02) = 0.056 = 5.6%.
answerFeedback.e98941c6-f390-4b9a-a98e-c1070cee5f24: Incorrect because it computes M2 instead of M2 alpha, which is an intermediate step in the correct calculation; M2 = 0.02 + 0.8 × 0.12 = 0.116 = 11.6%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Gagne-14
entry.itemBody: Which of the following measures is most appropriate to evaluate the performance of a portfolio that is not fully diversified?

answerFeedback.09958acb-e608-4111-a830-5b62c481fa65: Incorrect because performance measures relative to beta risk—Treynor ratio and Jensen’s alpha—are relevant when the investor holds a well-diversified portfolio with negligible diversifiable risk.
answerFeedback.7e8622d1-95a6-4737-bd1a-2bceebe9b184: Incorrect because performance measures relative to beta risk—Treynor ratio and Jensen’s alpha—are relevant when the investor holds a well-diversified portfolio with negligible diversifiable risk.
answerFeedback.a9c910ff-3d2d-4c16-b25a-ea6f40e780ea: Correct because total risk is relevant for an investor when he or she holds a portfolio that is not fully diversified, which is not a desirable portfolio. In such cases, the Sharpe ratio and M2 are appropriate performance measures. The Sharpe ratio uses total risk as a measure of risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Roberts-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following measures uses only systematic risk to evaluate portfolio performance?

answerFeedback.8c8cc5d6-c8af-4999-9dd9-7be6e01d0e1f: Correct because Jensen’s alpha is based on systematic risk. The difference between the actual portfolio return and the calculated risk-adjusted return is a measure of the portfolio’s performance relative to the market portfolio and is called Jensen’s alpha.
answerFeedback.a447c088-8eb9-40cc-9bb9-9677f7db2e60: Incorrect because the Sharpe ratio measure is based on total risk. Total risk is relevant for an investor when he or she holds a portfolio that is not fully diversified, which is not a desirable portfolio. In such cases, the Sharpe ratio and M2 are appropriate performance measures.
answerFeedback.b1cc1f75-6630-457b-a090-62310705a7f3: Incorrect because M2 provides a measure of portfolio return that is adjusted for the total risk of the portfolio relative to that of some benchmark.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Kennan-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a portfolio and the market:

Portfolio return 7.0%
Market return 5.0%
Risk-free return 1.0%
Portfolio beta 1.2

Jensen’s alpha for the portfolio is:

answerFeedback.1bedcffb-81d3-42da-96fb-1c5e2cf33862: Correct because Jensen’s alpha is defined as the portfolio return less (the risk-free rate plus the portfolio beta times (the market return minus the risk-free rate)). Therefore, Jensen's alpha = Rp – [Rf + βp(Rm – Rf)] = 7% – (1% + 1.2 × (5% – 1%)) = 7.0% – 5.8% = 1.2%.
answerFeedback.2c3caa7e-90cb-4120-9a9b-dd2984fb45b0: Incorrect because this omits the initial risk-free rate in the equation. Therefore, Jensen's alpha = Rp – βp[Rm – Rf] = 7% – (1.2 × (5% – 1%)) = 7.0% – 4.8% = 2.2%.
answerFeedback.d6512739-9d54-4596-8907-35d159ecb1c3: Incorrect because the market return is used instead of the market risk premium. Therefore, Jensen's alpha = Rp – [Rf + (βp × Rm)] = 7% – (1% + 1.2 × 5%) = 0.0%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08844
entry.itemBody: If all investors have homogeneous expectations, the total risk and expected return of portfolios consisting of the risk-free asset and the optimal risky portfolio are plotted on the:

answerFeedback.1b05c007-5336-4aa5-a494-1066a05aca41: Incorrect because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. Using the same concept as the capital market line, the SML intersects the y-axis at the risk-free rate of return, and the slope of this line is the market risk premium, Rm – Rf.
answerFeedback.bd7407b2-e785-4b31-8327-0296b076ef32: Correct because the risk-free asset could be combined with a risky portfolio to create a capital allocation line (CAL). A specific CAL that uses the market portfolio as the optimal risky portfolio is known as the capital market line. When assuming homogeneous expectations, only one optimal portfolio exists. The capital market line is shown in Exhibit 3, where the standard deviation (σp), or total risk, is on the x-axis and expected portfolio return, E(Rp), is on the y-axis.
answerFeedback.c4236aef-6481-4f82-875c-c3f233881b71: Incorrect because a security characteristic line (SCL) for a security is a plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09127
entry.itemBody: An investor who can lend and borrow at the risk-free rate builds a portfolio using the risk-free asset and the market portfolio. The risk-free rate is 3% and the expected market return is 15%. If the expected portfolio return is 18%, the investor's portfolio is:

answerFeedback.4dda31f9-9d79-48d9-ab73-a30179e729da: Incorrect because the expected market return is 15%, while the expected portfolio return is 18%. Since the two returns are different, the investor's portfolio is different from the optimal risky (market) portfolio.
answerFeedback.caee41b2-d1c3-4888-9515-26dba19b27c3:
Correct because a leveraged portfolio is a portfolio that has a negative investment in the risk-free asset.

A portfolio's expected return, E(Rp), is calculated as: E(Rp) = w1Rf + (1 – w1)E(Rm), where w1 is the proportion invested in the risk-free asset, returning Rf, and E(Rm) is the expected return on the market portfolio.

Thus, 0.18 = w1 × 0.03 + (1 – w1) × 0.15

0.18 – 0.15 = w1 × (0.03 – 0.15)

0.03 = w1 × (–0.12)

w1 = 0.03/(–0.12)

w1 = –0.25

A negative proportion invested in the risk-free rate implies a leveraged portfolio.
answerFeedback.f104f601-1162-4660-9be4-5c2c528f940e:
Incorrect because a lending portfolio is a portfolio that has a positive investment in the risk-free asset.

A portfolio's expected return, E(Rp), is calculated as: E(Rp) = w1Rf + (1 – w1)E(Rm), where w1 is the proportion invested in the risk-free asset, returning Rf, and E(Rm) is the expected return on the market portfolio.

Thus, 0.18 = w1 × 0.03 + (1 – w1) × 0.15

0.18 – 0.15 = w1 × (0.03 – 0.15)

0.03 = w1 × (–0.12)

w1 = 0.03/(–0.12)

w1 = –0.25

A negative proportion invested in the risk-free rate implies a leveraged, not a lending, portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09123
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three securities:

  Total Variance
of Returns		 Nonsystematic
Variance of Returns
Security 1 0.20 0.05
Security 2 0.30 0.25
Security 3 0.35 0.22

According to capital market theory, which security has the highest expected return?

answerFeedback.177e6f63-8c74-411b-8a37-699098a04f2f: Incorrect because Security 2 has the highest nonsystematic variance (risk) but the lowest systematic variance (risk), and investors should not be compensated for taking on nonsystematic risk. Since only systematic variance (risk) is compensated with a higher expected return, Security 2 has the lowest expected return.
answerFeedback.4b8df4c6-1bf6-459c-aeaf-3cf89d8b4e6e:
Correct because according to the capital market theory investors should not be compensated for taking on nonsystematic risk. In contrast, investors must be compensated for accepting systematic risk because that risk cannot be diversified away. In summary, systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Also, Total variance = Systematic variance + Nonsystematic variance. Thus,

Security 1 has systematic variance = 0.20 – 0.05 = 0.15;

Security 2 has systematic variance = 0.30 – 0.25 = 0.05;

Security 3 has systematic variance = 0.35 – 0.22 = 0.13.

Since only systematic variance (risk) is compensated with a higher expected return, Security 1 has the highest expected return.
answerFeedback.ff94a589-5571-49fa-82a6-a9077361093f: Incorrect because Security 3 has the highest total variance (risk) but not the highest systematic variance (risk), and investors should not be compensated for taking on nonsystematic risk. Since only systematic risk is compensated with a higher expected return, Security 3 does not have the highest expected return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06053
entry.itemBody: The risk–return trade-off of a portfolio of only risky assets most likely improves when a risk-free asset is added to the portfolio because:

answerFeedback.1861b0d8-2760-4f63-a4ff-24bb57b21e1e: Incorrect because the risk–return trade-off is improved by lower risk not a lower return. It is the zero correlation of the risk-free asset with the risky assets in the portfolio that lowers the risk level.
answerFeedback.2d9ac1dd-7b87-49d5-b91b-cbb2bf1a3da3: Incorrect because the correlations among the risky assets are unaffected by the addition of a risk-free asset to the portfolio. The risk–return trade-off is improved by the zero correlation of the risk-free asset with the risky assets in the portfolio, not a change in correlations among the risky assets.
answerFeedback.a94e7b16-ff9d-4737-8f8a-33c0b37b913c: Correct because an investor's portfolio improves if a risk-free asset is added to the mix. In other words, a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset.

choices.itemBody: A. the risk-free asset is uncorrelated with the other assets in the portfolio.
B. the lower return on the risk-free asset provides a diversification effect.
C. the correlations among the risky assets decrease, providing a diversification effect.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06268
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an asset and the market:

Risk-free rate 1%
Market risk premium 5%
Asset's expected return 5%

Based on the CAPM, the asset's beta is closest to:

answerFeedback.140713f7-e3b4-477f-a2b9-ed8f923f22b7: Incorrect because it does not subtract the risk-free rate in the numerator and calculates βi = E(Ri) / [E(Rm) – Rf] = 5%/5% = 1.0. It is also the answer if the market risk premium is confused with the market return, thus βi = [E>(Ri) – Rf] / [market risk premium – Rf] = [5% – 1%] / [5% – 1%] = 4%/4% = 1.0.
answerFeedback.7e5982df-3748-44fa-b625-17d2480dc056: Correct because the expected return of an asset is E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf], where Ri, Rm, and Rf denote the return on the asset, the market, and the risk-free asset, respectively, βi is the asset's beta, and [E(Rm) – Rf ] is the market risk premium. Thus, βi = [E(Ri) – Rf] / [E(Rm) – Rf] = [5% – 1%] / 5% = 4%/5% = 0.8.
answerFeedback.d7a44fe8-fa21-4bb1-a685-e88547e74456: Incorrect because it is the inverse of beta, 1/βi> = [E(Rm) – Rf] / [E(Ri) – Rf] = market risk premium / [E(Ri) – Rf] = 5% / [5% – 1%] = 5%/4% = 1.25. It is also the answer if two mistakes are made: The risk-free rate is not subtracted from the expected return in the numerator and the market risk premium is confused with the market return. Thus, βi = E(Ri) / [market risk premium – Rf] = 5% / [5% – 1%] = 5%/4% = 1.25.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06056
entry.itemBody: The slope of the security market line is most likely the:

answerFeedback.39ce2cc8-4fb1-494a-8255-70c135909d34: Correct because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. The slope of this line is the market risk premium, Rm – Rf.
answerFeedback.6215a8ad-7ee9-4eca-aaff-5f3055d0de36: Incorrect because it is the slope of the capital market line (CML), E(Rm) – Rf /σm not the security market line. Since the market standard deviation is unlikely to be 1, the slope of the CML is most likely not the slope of the SML.
answerFeedback.d1d793ee-7809-42e5-8004-36985fd3161d: Incorrect because the security's beta is the slope of the security characteristic line (SCL), not the security market line. The SCL is a plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market. The beta is the slope.

choices.itemBody: C. market risk premium divided by the market standard deviation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07385
entry.itemBody: The market model is most likely used to estimate:

answerFeedback.4babe9da-1c69-41e6-9ccc-c68e341f0c86: Incorrect because the market model does not explicitly consider the risk-free rate of return (unlike the single-index model).
answerFeedback.7774e420-a4b5-474f-b597-916e670b880c: Correct because the market model is normally used for estimating beta risk and computing abnormal returns. These parameter estimates are then used to predict company-specific returns that a security may earn in a future period.
answerFeedback.cbc6febd-143d-446e-ba1d-aa3fac3501fb: Incorrect because the market model takes the expected market return as given rather than predicting it.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04186
entry.itemBody: Unsystematic risk is best described as:

answerFeedback.4eaa237f-0787-4bac-af40-86ecfdf00d98: Correct because unsystematic (nonsystematic) risk can be diversified away.
answerFeedback.86bb0743-66a7-47aa-ba1f-2824526c8b27: Incorrect because the variability caused by macroeconomic variables is systematic (market) risk.
answerFeedback.e37b28db-78b7-4e66-9b7a-04772d91db5f: Incorrect because total risk includes both systematic and nonsystematic risk.

choices.itemBody: C. the variability in all risky assets caused by macroeconomic variables.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07721
entry.itemBody:
An analyst estimates the market model for an asset and obtains the following parameters:

Intercept (α) 1%
Slope coefficient (β) 0.5

 

If the market's expected return is 2%, the asset's expected return is:

answerFeedback.01f4d376-fcb7-4ca3-b3ed-705c7a3878ff: Correct because the expected return of an asset according to the market model is calculated as E(Ri) = α + β × E(Rm), where E(Rm) denotes the expected market return; 1% + 0.5 × 2% = 2%.
answerFeedback.3ed4d95f-7416-4da6-888c-9bcac4018a38: Incorrect because it mistakes α for the risk-free rate in the CAPM expected return calculation; 1% + 0.5 × (2% – 1%) = 1.5%. It is also the result of the incorrect calculation: β × [α +E(Rm)] = 0.5 × (1% + 2%) = 1.5%.
answerFeedback.5e0c0631-b3b0-408b-9883-5d469978e2e7: Incorrect because it neglects the constant term α in the correct calculation; 0.5 × 2% = 1%. It is also the expected market return minus the asset's alpha; 2% – 1% = 1%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Y.Zhang-07
entry.itemBody: With respect to multi-factor return-generating models, a company's earnings are best classified as a:

answerFeedback.1705c0c0-16bb-4631-8a78-b67881b4025c: Incorrect because, in a statistical factor model, historical and cross-sectional return data are analyzed to identify factors that explain variance or covariance in observed returns. Earnings is not a statistical factor but a fundamental factor. Fundamental factor models analyze and use relationships between security returns and the company’s underlying fundamentals, such as, for example, earnings.
answerFeedback.70f1208b-18fd-43a5-bf2d-2b358585f9a0: Incorrect because macroeconomic factor models use economic factors that are correlated with security returns. These factors may include economic growth, the interest rate, the inflation rate, productivity, employment, and consumer confidence. Earnings is not a macroeconomic factor but a fundamental factor. Fundamental factor models analyze and use relationships between security returns and the company’s underlying fundamentals, such as, for example, earnings
answerFeedback.7507a2f2-d8f7-41ef-bcfe-7610ca6d003c: Correct because a multi-factor model allows more than one variable to be considered in estimating returns and can be built using different kinds of factors, such as macroeconomic, fundamental, and statistical factors. Fundamental factor models analyze and use relationships between security returns and the company’s underlying fundamentals, such as, for example, earnings.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05225
entry.itemBody: The market portfolio's level of systematic risk is most likely:

answerFeedback.43cf17f9-df4d-4005-883e-276a32213b9f: Incorrect because nonsystematic risk is diversified away; therefore, systematic risk is greater than nonsystematic risk.
answerFeedback.61bc122e-793e-484a-9fac-3196cf5f7cd3: Incorrect because nonsystematic risk is diversified away; therefore, systematic risk is greater than nonsystematic risk.
answerFeedback.942a37d3-a1d7-434d-8fe9-59d0d95380ca: Correct because systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Investors do not receive any return for accepting nonsystematic or diversifiable risk. Also, investors are capable of avoiding nonsystematic risk through diversification by forming a portfolio of assets that are not highly correlated with one another. Thus, for a market portfolio, there is only systematic risk because nonsystematic risk is diversified away.

choices.itemBody: A. less than its level of nonsystematic risk.
B. equal to its level of nonsystematic risk.
C. greater than its level of nonsystematic risk.

entry.title: CFA0160-Q7

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The optimal risky portfolio is the market portfolio. Capital market theory assumes that investors have homogeneous expectations, which means that all investors analyze securities in the same way and are rational. That is, investors use the same probability distributions, use the same inputs for future cash flows, and arrive at the same valuations. Because their valuations of all assets are identical, all investors will invest in the same optimal risky portfolio (i.e., the market portfolio).

entry.itemBody: With respect to capital market theory, the optimal risky portfolio:

choices.itemBody: B. has the highest expected return.
C. has the lowest expected variance.

This means that there is negative investment in the risk-free asset, which is referred to as a leveraged position in the risky portfolio.

feedback.neutral: A is correct. M2 adjusts for risk using standard deviation (i.e., total risk).

entry.itemBody: Which of the following performance measures is most appropriate for an investor who is not fully diversified?

entry.title: CFA0160-Q22

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The security characteristic line is a plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market. In such a graph, Jensen’s alpha is the intercept and the beta is the slope.

entry.itemBody: The slope of the security characteristic line is an asset’s:

entry.title: CFA0160-Q36

feedback.neutral: B is correct. If the estimated return of an asset is above the SML (the expected return), the asset has a lower level of risk relative to the amount of expected return and would be a good choice for investment (i.e., undervalued).

entry.itemBody: Analysts who have estimated returns of an asset to be greater than the expected returns generated by the capital asset pricing model should consider the asset to be:

entry.title: CFA0160-Q39

feedback.neutral: C is correct. This is because of the plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market. In such a graph, Jensen’s alpha is the intercept and the beta is the slope.

entry.itemBody: The intercept of the best fit line formed by plotting the excess returns of a manager’s portfolio on the excess returns of the market is best described as Jensen’s:

entry.title: CFA0160-Q40

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Since managers are concerned with maximizing risk-adjusted returns, securities with a higher value of Jensen’s alpha, αi, should have a higher weight.

entry.itemBody: Portfolio managers who are maximizing risk-adjusted returns will seek to invest more in securities with:

choices.itemBody: A. lower values of Jensen’s alpha.
B. values of Jensen’s alpha equal to 0.
C. higher values of Jensen’s alpha.

entry.title: CFA0160-Q41

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Since managers are concerned with maximizing risk-adjusted returns, securities with greater nonsystematic risk should be given less weight in the portfolio.

entry.itemBody: Portfolio managers, who are maximizing risk-adjusted returns, will seek to invest less in securities with:

choices.itemBody: A. lower values for nonsystematic variance.
B. values of nonsystematic variance equal to 0.
C. higher values for nonsystematic variance.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606007
entry.itemBody: A return-generating model that provides an estimate of the expected return of a security based on such factors as earnings growth and cash flow generation is best described as a:

answerFeedback.1532abfc-ff83-46ae-8728-a9e350821dd3: Incorrect. In a market model, the factor is the market return.
answerFeedback.c2e2a9df-5c50-4b9b-8242-413c295aabdd: Incorrect. In a macroeconomic factor model, appropriate factors would be economic factors such as the interest rate and the inflation rate.
answerFeedback.c85afd85-4a97-4b10-9868-bcd5254d769c: Correct. A return-generating model based on such factors as earnings growth and cash flow generation is a fundamental factor model.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606012
entry.itemBody: An asset has an annual return of 19.9%, standard deviation of returns of 18.5%, and correlation with the market of 0.9. If the standard deviation of returns on the market is 15.9% and the risk-free rate is 1%, the beta of this asset is closest to:

answerFeedback.26fcf279-f298-41d8-84fc-59051f5f45f5: Incorrect. It is the ratio of the standard deviation of the asset to the standard deviation of the market: (18.5%/15.9%) = 1.16.
answerFeedback.ed3a41b2-0ee9-4b4b-8fc6-54d28100cd16: Incorrect. It calculates the Sharpe ratio instead of beta: (19.9% – 1.0%)/18.5% = 1.02.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606035
entry.itemBody: A portfolio with equal parts invested in a risk-free asset and a risky portfolio will most likely lie on:

answerFeedback.99045957-8f93-4206-8ae8-1a53acc2d647: Incorrect. A portfolio that is 100% invested in an efficient risky portfolio will lie on the efficient frontier. When combined with a risk-free asset, the resulting portfolio will lie on a capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.ac84cda4-4f01-4d02-99af-f1033af6e35a: Correct. A capital allocation line shows possible combinations of a risky portfolio and the risk-free asset.
answerFeedback.ad858d32-36ee-46f6-b821-4c6e6d4f97d2: Incorrect. Only a portfolio with 50% in a risk-free asset and 50% in the market portfolio will lie on the capital market line.

entry.title: ITEM_20170421060
entry.itemBody:
The following information is available on three portfolios:

Portfolio Mean Return on
the Portfolio (%)		 Standard Deviation of
the Return on the Portfolio
D 10 20
E 18 15
F 6 3

The risk-free rate is 4%. The portfolio that has the best risk-adjusted performance as measured by the Sharpe ratio is:

answerFeedback.9aa7d88f-2200-42fe-ac80-3d0b6fbd4e69: Incorrect. There are numerous possible mistakes that would lead a candidate to choose Portfolio D. Foremost among them would be putting the standard deviations in the numerators rather than the denominators of the Sharpe ratios. The coefficient of variation is an example: Portfolio D: 20/10 = 2; Portfolio E: 15/18 = 0.83; and Portfolio F: 3/6 = 0.5.
answerFeedback.c80dbbaa-eb59-43bd-bd8d-294351a847fc:
Correct.

SD = (10 − 4)/20 = 0.30

SE = (18 − 4)/15 = 0.9333

SF = (6 − 4)/3 = 0.6667

The portfolio with the best risk-adjusted performance as measured by the Sharpe ratio is the one with the highest Sharpe ratio: Portfolio E.
answerFeedback.fa721444-5fca-4493-9983-767f4a2c58c8: Incorrect. There are numerous possible mistakes that would lead a candidate to choose Portfolio F. Foremost among them would be failing to subtract the risk-free rate from the mean return of the portfolios. Portfolio D: 10/20 = 0.5; Portfolio E: 18/15 = 1.2; Portfolio F: 6/3 = 2.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606005
entry.itemBody: The stock of GBK Corporation has a beta of 0.65. If the risk-free rate of return is 3% and the expected market return is 9%, the expected return for GBK is closest to:

entry.title: ITEM_20170606013
entry.itemBody: Which of the following performance measures most likely relies on systematic risk as opposed to total risk when calculating a risk-adjusted return?

answerFeedback.0724fda2-8729-4af7-93dc-e637476eb750: Incorrect. The Sharpe ratio is similar to the Treynor ratio, but it uses portfolio standard deviation, which is a measure of total risk, instead of standard deviation.
answerFeedback.4297bb72-a9d4-42e6-b5d8-4cb0abc59698: Correct. The Treynor ratio measures the return premium of a portfolio versus the risk-free asset relative to the portfolio’s beta, which is a measure of systematic risk.
answerFeedback.ca67b0d6-957b-441d-830f-5e5b6214d97f: Incorrect. M-squared incorporates the standard deviation of the market and portfolio, which are measures of total risk.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606017
entry.itemBody: An investor with $10,000 decides to borrow an additional $5,000 at the risk-free rate and invest all the available funds in the market portfolio. This investor’s portfolio beta is closest to:

answerFeedback.2afe650f-4d8c-4423-9de5-9190d3961b67: Incorrect. It is computed using weights of 0.5 for the risk-free asset and the market portfolio, that is: 0(0.5) + 1(0.5) = 0.5.
answerFeedback.893ff762-71a7-4a87-b2d8-3b61c58217a5: Incorrect. It is the market portfolio’s beta.
answerFeedback.ed8382da-b8b8-41d8-b2bc-14e7d6719cfd: Correct. The weight in the market portfolio is 15,000/10,000 = 1.5 and the weight in the risk-free asset is –5,000/10,000 = –0.5. Because the beta of the risk-free asset is 0 and the market portfolio’s beta is 1, the portfolio’s beta is βp = 0(–0.5) + 1(1.5) = 1.5.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606018
entry.itemBody: Stock X and Stock Y have the same level of total risk. Stock X has twice the systematic risk of Stock Y and half its non-systematic risk. Stock X’s expected return will most likely be:

answerFeedback.97ff1be3-c827-4de2-acba-12b1c32fcb34: Incorrect. Stock X has a higher systematic risk level compared to Stock Y, implying a higher (not the same) expected return compared to Stock Y.
answerFeedback.9c9618c4-b5a6-46ef-b8f4-9de8ae84722f: Incorrect. Stock X has a higher systematic risk level compared to Stock Y, implying a higher (not lower) expected return compared to Stock Y.
answerFeedback.be4f8008-9f58-48e8-95ae-098a4846af34: Correct. Stock X has a higher systematic risk level compared with Stock Y, its expected return will be higher than that of Stock Y.

choices.itemBody: A. the same as the expected return of Stock Y.
B. lower than the expected return of Stock Y.
C. higher than the expected return of Stock Y.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606021
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely an assumption underlying the capital asset pricing model (CAPM)?

answerFeedback.3883614f-1891-4bb5-afa8-4d8ad86b7fb7: Incorrect. An investor being able to invest as much or as little in an asset (that is, investments are infinitely divisible) is an assumption of the CAPM.
answerFeedback.6e252455-7775-4bdc-aadc-456ffde0cfb7: Incorrect. No restrictions on short selling assets (which is an assumption underlying frictionless markets) is an assumption of the CAPM.
answerFeedback.9a2589cd-a2ce-4766-b1b9-cb5deb499136: Correct. The CAPM requires that there are no restrictions on short selling (which is an assumption underlying frictionless markets) and that the amount invested in an asset can be as much or as little as the investor wants (that is, investments are infinitely divisible). The CAPM also assumes that all investors analyze securities in the same way using the same inputs for future cash flows and the same probability distributions; that is, it assumes that investors have homogenous expectations.

choices.itemBody: A. Investors analyze securities according to their own future cash flow estimates and probability distributions.
B. There are no restrictions on short selling assets.
C. The amount invested in an asset can be as much or as little as the investor wants.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606023
entry.itemBody: An analyst uses a multi-factor model to estimate the expected returns of various securities. The model analyzes historical and cross-sectional return data to identify factors that explain the variance or covariance in the securities’ observed returns. This model is most likely a:

answerFeedback.72fa131f-1cd0-4dbc-b9a9-ec5f052277c2: Incorrect because fundamental factor models use the relationships between security returns and firms’ underlying fundamentals, such as earnings, earnings growth, cash flow generation, investment in research, etc.
answerFeedback.a1065e73-8e67-4ca6-9caf-47a5081fc5a9: Correct because statistical factor models use historical and cross-sectional return data to identify factors that explain the variance or covariance in the observed returns of securities.
answerFeedback.e2c16891-8638-45a2-b9c4-34d886583d85: Incorrect because macroeconomic factor models use economic factors that are correlated with security returns, such as economic growth, the interest rate, the inflation rate, productivity, etc.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606024
entry.itemBody: Following its decision to divest its non-core assets, analysts expect HCL Corp’s standard deviation of returns to rise to 30% and its correlation with the market portfolio to remain unchanged at 0.8. The risk-free rate and the market risk premium are expected to remain unchanged at 6% and 8%, respectively. The market portfolio’s standard deviation of returns, however, is expected to decrease to 15%. The firm’s expected return after the restructure is closest to:

answerFeedback.85b6975b-e2fe-4b8d-81de-ccfa6f973569: Incorrect. The beta is incorrectly calculated as [(0.8 × 0.15)/0.30] = 0.4, resulting in an expected return of 0.06 + (0.08)0.4 = 9.2%.
answerFeedback.a2666029-67d1-4c7d-8706-a10c04bec330: Incorrect. The expected return is incorrectly calculated as 0.08 + (0.06)1.6 = 17.6%.
answerFeedback.e1045dbf-fa37-4c7c-8926-8d5c9db2cab3:
Correct. We first compute the firm’s beta using

β i = ρ i,m σ i σ m

The beta is

β i = 0.8( 0.30 ) 0.15 =1.6

The expected return is computed using

E(Ri) = Rf + [E(Rm) – Rf]βi

So, E(Ri) = 0.06 + (0.08)1.6 = 18.8%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606025
entry.itemBody: Which of the following portfolio performance measures are the most appropriate for an investor who holds a fully diversified portfolio?

answerFeedback.b9091081-51d2-4015-8e02-92044d183828: Correct. For an investor who holds a fully diversified portfolio, the Treynor ratio and Jensen’s alpha are the appropriate portfolio performance measures. They are appropriate because in a fully diversified portfolio, only systematic risk matters; both these metrics measure performance relative to beta or systematic risk.
answerFeedback.e334bc8a-e628-494c-8f7e-9729dfc3f2e6: Incorrect. These measures are appropriate for an investor who does not hold a fully diversified portfolio.
answerFeedback.fc2e8eb4-5d90-4605-8cef-a0869aec4133: Incorrect. The Treynor ratio is appropriate for an investor who holds a fully diversified portfolio, but the Sharpe ratio is appropriate for an investor who does not hold a fully diversified portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606026
entry.itemBody: Based on the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), the expected return on FGL Corp’s shares is 12%. Using a model independent of the CAPM, an analyst has estimated the returns on the stock at 10%. Based on this information, the analyst is most likely to consider the stock to be:

answerFeedback.3884f840-d903-4899-82ae-e32409b0cd03: Correct. Because the estimated return on the stock is lower than the expected return using the CAPM, the stock does not compensate the investor for the level of risk and so it is most likely overvalued.
answerFeedback.60cc9888-4be9-4766-a9dc-7034fd66ee2b: Incorrect. Because the estimated return on the stock is lower than the expected return using the CAPM, the stock does not compensate the investor for the level of risk and so it is most likely overvalued (not undervalued).
answerFeedback.d947eeac-15bd-40b9-8f07-fee0d4826c57: Incorrect. Because the estimated return on the stock is lower than the expected return using the CAPM, the stock does not compensate the investor for the level of risk and so it is most likely overvalued (not correctly valued).

entry.title: ITEM_20170606034
entry.itemBody:
The following table shows data for the stock of JKU and a market index.

Expected return of JKU 15%
Expected return of market index 12%
Risk-free rate 5%
Standard deviation of JKU returns 20%
Standard deviation of market index returns 15%
Correlation of JKU and market index returns 0.75

Based on the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), JKU is most likely:

answerFeedback.17c59343-3911-4796-a0b3-66b2a7c1d22d: Incorrect. For JKU to be overvalued it would need to have an expected return less than 12%.
answerFeedback.5549c65b-2cb4-4be7-adcf-c89d52f6355a: Incorrect. For JKU to be properly valued it would need to have an expected return equal to 12%.
answerFeedback.56235986-1e74-4b36-9789-caa29dfb62aa:
Correct.

βJKU = (ρJKU,M × σJKU)/σM = (0.75 × 0.2)/0.15 = 1.0

and

E(RJKU) = Rf + βJKU × (RM – Rf) = 0.05 + 1 × (0.12 – 0.05) = 0.12

The required rate of return of JKU is 12%, and the expected return of JKU is 15%. Therefore, JKU is undervalued relative to the security market line (SML); the risk–return relationship lies above the SML.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606038
entry.itemBody: The slope of the security market line (SML) represents the portion of an asset’s expected return attributable to:

answerFeedback.5a7bf3b2-5347-48ae-874c-629979f584b9: Incorrect. Diversifiable risk is the unique risk related to any security and, as such, is a component of total risk.
answerFeedback.7be1950a-c68c-406a-9d36-6e48c36bcd54: Incorrect. Total risk is equal to market (systematic) risk and unsystematic (diversifiable) risk.
answerFeedback.8ba43d89-24ac-4448-b670-3caf56cd3bf7: Correct. The slope of the SML is the market risk premium, E(Rm) – Rf. It represents the return of the market minus the return of a risk-free asset. Thus, the slope represents the portion of expected return that reflects compensation for market or systematic risk.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606040
entry.itemBody:
Information about three stocks is provided in the following table:

Stock Expected Return Beta
Booraem Inc. 12.85% 1.5
Heisen Inc. 11.27% 1.1
Gutmann Inc. 9.51% 0.8

If the expected market return is 9.5% and the average risk-free rate is 1.2%, according to the capital asset pricing model (CAPM) and the security market line (SML), which of the three stocks is most likely overvalued?

answerFeedback.1f473b4f-2deb-432e-a2ef-4b787a5ee29b: Incorrect. Heisen Inc. is undervalued because it lies above the SML. The expected return, 11.27%, exceeds the required return. According to the CAPM the required return for Heisen Inc. is 0.1033 or 10.33%: 0.1033 = 0.012 + 1.1(0.095 – 0.012).
answerFeedback.5ba4ec74-e16b-44ea-9a92-4708ebc442e3: Incorrect. Gutmann Inc. is undervalued because it lies above the SML. The expected return, 9.51%, exceeds the required return. According to the CAPM the required return for Gutmann Inc. is 0.0784 or 7.84%: 0.0784 = 0.012 + 0.8(0.095 – 0.012).
answerFeedback.93eee71a-bcba-4e57-9534-9dc30c131fba: Correct. Booraem Inc. is overvalued because it lies below the SML. The expected return, 12.85%, is less than the required return. According to the CAPM, the required return for Booraem Inc. is 0.1365 or 13.65%: 0.1365 = 0.012 + 1.5(0.095 – 0.012).

entry.title: ITEM_20170606045
entry.itemBody: Risk that can be attributed to factor(s) that affect a company or industry is best described as:

answerFeedback.abc28e3a-6d12-444b-8cd2-9883b1ce5d4e: Incorrect because systematic risk is the same as market risk. It is due to factors that impact the whole market.
answerFeedback.c91fd356-1ba6-4777-b5ec-a38123ffe3b6: Incorrect because market risk is the same as systematic risk. It is due to factors that impact the whole market.
answerFeedback.e9bfc191-302f-4009-a87c-e2da9e2c479e: Correct because risk that is attributable to company-specific or industry-specific factors is referred to as non-systematic risk.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606076
entry.itemBody:
The following information is provided about a stock market index m and security i:

Statistic Value
Covariance between market return and security return [Cov(Ri,Rm)] 0.01104
Correlation coefficient between market return and security return (ρi,m) 0.3
Standard deviation of market return (σm) 0.16

The beta of security i, βi, is closest to:

answerFeedback.0c7c1891-6e83-4d6d-a095-2942113581e8: Incorrect. Instead of Cov(Ri,Rm), ρi,m is used in the formula: 0.3/(0.16)2 = 1.88.
answerFeedback.3ece01ba-7459-4fb4-bbc0-483b3837b9a4:
Incorrect. This is the value for σi.

σi = Cov(Ri,Rm)/(σm × ρi,m) = 0.01104/(0.16 × 0.3) = 0.23

entry.title: ITEM_20170606077
entry.itemBody: A security has a beta of 1.30. If the risk-free rate of interest is 3% and the expected return of the market is 8%, based on the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), the expected return of the security is closest to:

answerFeedback.508d9bb0-7f09-4fa0-a4e2-90355af5fa83: Incorrect. The market return is incorrectly interpreted as the market risk premium: 3% + 1.3 × 8% = 13.4%.
answerFeedback.750a0488-9f0a-466a-8e1b-0cfa3e9162db: Correct. The formula for the CAPM is expressed as E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf] or 3% + [1.3 × (8% – 3%)] = 9.5%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07481
entry.itemBody: According to capital market theory, an efficient market does not reward investors for taking on:

answerFeedback.51ac3176-d870-4a31-bb9a-c95ed5243afa: Correct because we can assume that in an efficient market, no incremental reward can be earned for taking on diversifiable risk. Nonsystematic risk is the risk that pertains to a single company or industry and is also known as company-specific, industry-specific, diversifiable, or idiosyncratic risk.
answerFeedback.5b3e1b13-dcd9-423d-a6d1-03dd2b219551: Incorrect because systematic risk, also known as non-diversifiable or market risk, is the risk that affects the entire market or economy. Systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Investors do not receive any return for accepting nonsystematic or diversifiable risk.
answerFeedback.db1a0fb6-10d9-4c83-9412-1dbbe6e65214: Incorrect because systematic risk, also known as non-diversifiable or market risk, is the risk that affects the entire market or economy. Systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Investors do not receive any return for accepting nonsystematic or diversifiable risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Roberts-02
entry.itemBody: A portfolio has an annual return of 15.2% and a standard deviation of returns of 11.7%. If the risk-free rate is 3.1%, the portfolio's Sharpe ratio is closest to:

answerFeedback.867dfe80-0579-4d9b-8786-756a0a20c72f: Correct because the Sharpe ratio is defined as the portfolio’s risk premium divided by its risk. Hence, the Sharpe ratio = (Rp – Rf) / σp = (15.2% – 3.1%) / 11.7% = 12.1% / 11.7% = 1.0342 ≈ 1.03.
answerFeedback.a1dd0cf6-2e71-4369-b602-96032c013000: Incorrect because it omits the risk-free rate when determining the portfolio's risk premium. Hence, the Sharpe ratio = Mean Annual Return/Standard Deviation of Return = 15.2% / 11.7% = 1.2991 ≈ 1.30.
answerFeedback.f238fd71-c250-416b-a401-90c1a8aecca1: Incorrect because the risk-free rate is added to (not subtracted from) the portfolio's return to determine the risk premium. Hence, the Sharpe ratio = (Rp + Rf) / σp = (15.2% + 3.1%) / 11.7% 18.3% / 11.7% = 1.5641 ≈ 1.56.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09006
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three stocks:

  Beta Standard Deviation of Returns
Stock 1 0.9 17%
Stock 2 1.1 18%
Stock 3 1.2 16%

If the standard deviation of market returns is equal to 10%, the stock with the highest nonsystematic risk is:

answerFeedback.2cdd2cbe-379a-4c1f-8dfa-f020f225b6f3: Incorrect because Stock 2 has the highest total risk, not the highest nonsystematic risk. Total risk is calculated as the square root of total variance.
answerFeedback.32022e87-58c9-472a-914b-34b7a222c4bb: Incorrect because Stock 3 has the highest beta and thus highest systematic risk, not the highest nonsystematic risk. Systematic risk is calculated as βiσm.
answerFeedback.40b07abd-f4fa-40f2-8374-c148e0ebd2cd: Correct because Total variance = Systematic variance + Nonsystematic variance, which can be written as σi2 = βi2σm2 + σe2. Thus, σe2 = σi2 – βi2σm2. Thus, nonsystematic variance for Stock 1 is equal to (0.17)2 – (0.9)2(0.1)2 = 0.0208. For Stock 2, this is equal to (0.18)2 – (1.1)2(0.1)2 = 0.0203. For Stock 3, this is equal to (0.16)2 – (1.2)2(0.1)2 = 0.0112. Therefore, Stock 1 has the highest nonsystematic variance and the highest idiosyncratic risk. Nonsystematic risk is the risk that pertains to a single company or industry and is also known as company-specific, industry-specific, diversifiable, or idiosyncratic risk.
